cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 after a data gap in real-time from 2025-12-22T18:12Z to 2025-12-23T00:22Z. The CME is also visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 and the north in STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption seen lifting off of the NE limb starting at 2025-12-23T20:21Z in SDO AIA 304. Opening field lines are also seen in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA and SDO AIA 193. No eruption signature is seen on the disk, so the filament footpoints are likely beyond the NE limb. The eruption is not visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the source location beyond the NE limb.

cmes.note: CME visible to the SW in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption near the west limb as seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery starting at 2025-12-23T14:36Z. The eruption is also seen in STEREO A EUV 304 imagery on the disk, around S05W90. Dimming is seen in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the source location.

cmes.note: Very faint and narrow CME first seen to the SSE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-24T10:36Z. This event is not clearly seen in any other coronagraphs. There is no clear source seen for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to uncertain source and lack of usable coronagraph imagery. Measurement made using SOHO LASCO C2 only.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north/northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery and to the north in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption visible on or slightly beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304, GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304, and STEREO A EUVI 304 imagery starting around 2025-12-25T05:00Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME observed to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The potential source for this CME is a small eruption south of AR 14319 (S10E30) starting at 2025-12-25T15:58Z in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. No source for this CME was observed, but the triangulation of the faint front fits around S20E30, and could vary slightly.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 and covered by a daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. It is following in the footsteps of the 2025-12-25T18:53Z CME. No clear source for this CME has been found in EUV imagery but there is a very minor eruption/ejecta off the SE limb starting at 2025-12-25T23:13Z in GOES SUVI 304 imagery, and also some super minor activity S of AR 14319 (S09E30).

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky analysis based on SOHO LASCO imagery. The CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO coronagraph and no clear source has been found.

cmes.note: Faint narrow jet seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs. It is covered by pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky analysis with SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraph. No source found for this event.

cmes.note: CME seen to the SW in STEREO A COR2 and to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, indicating a far-sided event (with longitude between -129 and -179 deg). It is possibly seen very faintly in two timestamps of GOES CCOR-1. There seems to be a narrower brighter bulk and a much wider very faint shock, with the shock clearly seen in one timestamp of COR2 and multiple timestamps of C3; faintly seen in C2. No source has been found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No coronal signatures of the far-sided source have been found in EUV imagery.
Analysis of the very faint likely shock front based on the fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO, STEREO A COR2). The source is far-sided.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery and not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap in real-time starting at 2025-12-26T18:38Z. The source for this event is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is an M5.1 class flare from AR 14325 (S09E72) observed in SDO AIA 131 which peaked at 2025-12-27T01:50Z, also observed as field line movement and post-eruptive arcades in SDO AIA 171/193/211/304 that appear to deflect NE of the eruption source. This deflection is further corroborated by the triangulation of the CME longitude to around E95-E100 in the swpc_cat tool.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The CME front appears quite deflected from the source, triangulating well around E95-E100 despite the observed eruption source in SDO AIA imagery at S09E72.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. Front develops very slowly at the start time in LASCO C2, speeding up as it travels further out. No distinct source is observed for this CME in available imagery, but it may be outflow following CME 2025-12-27T02:12Z associated with field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/304 that began for that CME around 2025-12-27T01:41Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint jet-like CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, and N and more faint in STEREO A COR2. The source is likely field line movement from AR 14312 starting around 2025-12-27T14:06Z in SDO AIA 171, centered around N16W60, with noticable observed deflection to the N from this source.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only plane-of-sky due to a <10 half width, and noticable deflection northward that does not allow good tracking of the CME front direction with the swpc_cat lemniscate.

cmes.note: CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely from former AR 14322, located near N13W86, observed as field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/304 starting around 2025-12-27T16:21Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between 2 frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and 1 frame of STEREO A COR2 due to data gaps beginning at 2025-12-27T17:36Z and 2025-12-27T17:38Z respectively. CME front is deflected slightly northward, not perfectly fitting the swpc_cat lemniscate, but tracked as well as possible for this analysis.

cmes.note: Faint narrow CME visible to the NW SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to the pilon. It is difficult to see this CME in white-light imagery (more noticeable in GOES CCOR-1) due to its faintness. There is no clear source for this CME. Moving/opening field lines are visible along the NW limb, however they appear associated with a separate CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 202512-28T23:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2025-12-28T17:53Z. The source of this event is an M4.2 flare from N08W28 which peaked at 2025-12-28T22:39Z as seen in SDO AIA 131. A wide region of dimming stretching towards the South and West can be seen in SDO AIA 193 and 211, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. STEREO A COR2 was not available for this measurement.

cmes.note: CME faintly visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 only. The potential source is a filament eruption starting around 2025-12-29T07:21Z from approximately S20E70 as seen in SDO AIA 304, but most of the material appears to fall back onto the solar disk. The eruption is not visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location. This measurement uses limited available SOHO LASCO C2 imagery due to the CME's faintness.

cmes.note: CME seen to the east in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2. The source is not found, and the CME is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using GOES CCOR-1 running difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Faint high N latitude CME with a loop-like front seen to the N in all three coronagraphs but mostly in difference imagery. The front is faint and difficult to trace because it has a brighter feature followed by a more distinct darker loop. No clear source has been found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of the faint front of this CME with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No clear source has been found to confirm this measurement.

cmes.note: Faint CME with a loop-like front seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs and not seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph. A faint but distinct source is likely a minor eruption W of Active Region 14317, centered around (N10W50), happening over 2025-12-29T08Z-11Z and seen as minor dimming and faint but high-rising post-eruptive arcades, as seen in SDO AIA 195 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph (SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1) analysis based on the likely (but rather faint) source: eruption W of AR 14317. The CME front is not seen in STEREO A COR2, so this analysis cannot be corroborated by triangulation.

cmes.note: CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. Not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption best seen starting around 2025-12-29T15:04Z in SDO AIA 193, around S20E75, characterized by dimming and opening field lines.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 running difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2025-12-29T16:53Z. The source is an eruption centered near N30E65 starting around 2025-12-29T18:30Z seen in SDO AIA 131/171/194/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. A wide opening of field lines is observed over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery at this time. Additionally, dimming is observed near the eruption site starting around 2025-12-29T19:00Z and post eruptive arcades begin to form around 2025-12-29T20:25Z as seen in SDO AIA 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source longitude. A triangulated measurement was not available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2025-12-29T16:53Z. The source is an eruption centered near S10W63 starting around 2025-12-29T19:40Z seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 imagery and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. Post eruptive arcades are visible starting around 2025-12-29T21:00Z in SDO AIA 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source longitude. A triangulated measurement was not available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.
